query: What GPA do graduate students need to be eligible for graduation?
reference_answer: Graduate students MUST have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to be eligible for graduation.

query: What is the minimum grade for earning graduate credit?
reference_answer: Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B- or higher.
nuggets: graduate credit only granted for courses completed with B- or higher

query: How many credits below B- lead to dismissal from the Graduate School?
reference_answer: Graduate students receiving grades below "B-" in 9 or more credits, including undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student, will be dismissed from the Graduate School.
nuggets: 9 or more credits below B- leads to dismissal
includes undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student

query: What happens if an accelerated master’s student earns below B- in a graduate course while in dual status?
reference_answer: Graduate students enrolled under the accelerated master's program receiving any grade below "B-" in a graduate course while in dual status may be dismissed and have their admission to the Graduate School withdrawn.
nuggets: receiving any grade below B- may result in dismissal
admission to the Graduate School may be withdrawn
applies to accelerated master's students in dual status

query: How many chances do master’s or Ed.S. students get to pass their final exam?
reference_answer: Graduate students will have a maximum of two opportunities to successfully complete final examinations for the master's or Ed.S. degree.
nuggets: applies to master's and Ed.S. final exams

query: How many chances do Ph.D. students get to pass qualifying or final exams?
reference_answer: Doctoral students will have a maximum of two opportunities to successfully complete qualifying or final examinations for the Ph.D. degree.
nuggets: applies to Ph.D. qualifying or final exams

query: What must conditionally admitted graduate students do to remain in the Graduate School?
reference_answer: Graduate students admitted on a conditional basis must meet the conditions as stated in the letter of admission in order to remain in the Graduate School.
nuggets: required to remain in Graduate School

query: Can programs set stricter academic standards than the Graduate School?
reference_answer: Each individual program may set and announce standards for coursework, examinations, and/or research achievement that are more rigorous than the Graduate School standard. Students may be dismissed if they accumulate fewer than 9 credits below the "B-" level or fail to make adequate progress in other aspects of their program.
nuggets: possible dismissal with fewer than 9 credits below B-
programs may dismiss for inadequate progress

query: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
reference_answer: To appeal a dismissal decision, a student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification.
nuggets: appeal must be submitted within 10 business days

query: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
reference_answer: A department chairperson or graduate program coordinator, upon recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal. The associate dean of the Graduate School acts on the recommendation and informs the student.
nuggets: chair/program coordinator recommends after faculty committee input
associate dean decides and informs student

query: Can I appeal a dismissal?
reference_answer: To appeal a dismissal decision, a student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification.

query: How many graduate credits are required for a master’s degree at UNH?
reference_answer: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog.
nuggets: minimum of 30 graduate credits required for all master's degrees
many programs require more than 30 credits
program-specific requirements are in program descriptions

query: Can 700-level courses count for graduate credit?
reference_answer: In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-level courses, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken for a letter grade.
nuggets: in rare cases students may petition to earn up to 12 credits of 700-level courses for graduate credit
700-level credits must be outside the student's degree program
advisor, graduate program coordinator, and Graduate School dean must approve
such courses must be taken for a letter grade

query: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
reference_answer: All master’s degrees at UNH must include a capstone experience. Such experiences may include a single integrative course, a performance, an internship or praxis, a portfolio, a scholarly paper or essay, an examination, a research problem, a research project, or a thesis.
nuggets: all master's degrees at UNH must include a capstone experience
examples include integrative course, performance, internship or praxis, portfolio, paper or essay, exam, research problem, research project, or thesis

query: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
reference_answer: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.
nuggets: minimum of three academic years of graduate study required for the Ph.D
one full academic year must be in residence at UNH
approved resident work at other universities may count toward the minimum

query: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
reference_answer: A minimum of two semesters of registration in Doctoral Research is required for Ph.D students. However, Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for 999 each semester during the academic year, even if the minimum requirement has been met. Although Doctoral Research (999) is 0 credits, it grants full-time student status.
nuggets: minimum of two semesters of Doctoral Research (999) required for Ph.D. students
students at candidacy must register for 999 each semester of the academic year

query: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
reference_answer: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee. Students are expected to file an Advancement to Candidacy form with the Graduate School as soon as possible after all of the requirements for candidacy have been met.
nuggets: advancement to candidacy occurs after passing the qualifying exam
student must meet language or proficiency requirements set by the program
student must declare a dissertation topic and fully form the doctoral committee
dean advances the student upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator
students must file an Advancement to Candidacy form once requirements are met

query: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
reference_answer: Qualified senior students at the University of New Hampshire may be admitted to an approved accelerated graduate program in the Graduate School provided they have followed normal application procedures; they must have been admitted for the semester in which they wish to enroll in courses for dual credit. A 3.20 cumulative grade point average is normally required to be considered for the program. Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both the bachelor's and master's degrees. Up to 8 credits, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, may count towards both the bachelor's degree and a graduate certificate.
nuggets: qualified UNH seniors may be admitted to an approved accelerated graduate program
a 3.20 cumulative GPA is normally required
students may take up to 12 credits of 800-level courses before completing the bachelor's degree
with department recommendation and Graduate School approval, such courses may count toward both bachelor's and master's degrees
up to 8 credits may, with approval, count toward both the bachelor's degree and a graduate certificate

query: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
reference_answer: Typically requires a 3.20 GPA; students may take up to 12 credits of 800-level courses before finishing the bachelor’s; with approval, up to 8 credits may count toward a graduate certificate; credits can count toward both bachelor’s and master’s as approved.
nuggets: Up to 12 credits at 800 level pre-bachelor’s
Up to 8 credits may count to grad certificate

query: Can I do a dual degree?
reference_answer: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed in the policy. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Students will receive separate diplomas for each degree program. Dual degrees will NOT be awarded retroactively.
nuggets: Credit only for graded coursework B- or higher

query: How do I reach degree candidacy?
reference_answer: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy after passing the qualifying examination, meeting program proficiency requirements, declaring a dissertation topic, and forming the doctoral dissertation committee. Students are expected to file an Advancement to Candidacy form once requirements are met.

query: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
reference_answer: All graduate work for any master’s degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation. Extensions may be considered on a case-by-case basis. Years on leave do not count toward the time limit.

query: Do I need RCR training?
reference_answer: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester.
nuggets: All incoming Ph.D. must complete RCR
Training due by end of first semester

query: What is a non-terminal degree?
reference_answer: Ph.D. students may petition to earn a non-terminal master’s degree while completing the Ph.D., provided they complete the master’s degree requirements for their program.
nuggets: Ph.D. students may earn non-terminal master's

query: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
reference_answer: A thesis student must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. No thesis credit is given until the thesis is approved, and acceptance is recorded with a grade of CR.

query: What does an AF grade mean?
reference_answer: An "AF" grade, Administrative F, is assigned for failure to either drop or complete a course. An "AF" is considered the same as an "F."
nuggets: Assigned if not dropped or completed

query: When is a CR grade used?
reference_answer: A "CR" grade is assigned for successful completion of specific Credit/Fail courses such as thesis/dissertation and other approved seminars.

query: What does an AU grade mean?
reference_answer: An "AU" grade is assigned for completion of courses for which an audit was granted. No credit is earned.

query: How does an Incomplete (IC) work for graduate courses?
reference_answer: An "IC" grade is assigned with the approval of the instructor for excused unfinished work only. The work must be completed by the agreed date, but not later than the last day of classes of the semester immediately following for 800- and 900-level courses, or by the mid-semester deadline for 400-, 500-, 600-, and 700-level courses. Extensions require a petition and are rarely granted beyond one calendar year.

query: What does NR mean on a graduate record?
reference_answer: "NR" indicates "Not Resolved: pending academic integrity allegation".

query: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
reference_answer: If a student submits an approved petition to drop a course during the withdrawal period, a "W" will be recorded. Failure to officially withdraw results in an "AF." Not attending classes does not constitute withdrawal. Deadlines are listed in the Academic Calendar.

query: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
reference_answer: Only the most recent grade is included in the cumulative GPA, and only the most recent credit is included in cumulative credits earned. A course may be repeated only once, and only repeated courses taken at UNH alter the GPA. Failing a required course for a second time is grounds for dismissal.

query: What is an IA grade?
reference_answer: "IA" indicates "incomplete" in thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. Prior semester "IA" grades remain on the official transcript, and only the final term of doctoral research may receive a "CR."
nuggets: Earlier IA terms remain on transcript

query: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
reference_answer: An "IC" grade is assigned for excused unfinished work with instructor approval and must be completed by the stated deadline. "IA" indicates an incomplete in multi-semester work such as thesis or doctoral research; earlier IA grades remain on the transcript, and only the final term may receive CR.
nuggets: IC = excused unfinished work with deadline
IA = multi-semester incomplete; earlier IA remain

query: Can I appeal a course grade?
reference_answer: Yes. Students must first discuss the evaluation with the instructor. If unresolved, they may seek redress from the department or program chair. In exceptional circumstances, a final appeal may be made to the dean of the college or school.

query: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?
reference_answer: Graduate courses cannot be taken pass/fail. A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis, but 700-level courses approved for graduate credit cannot be taken pass/fail.
nuggets: 700-level for grad credit cannot be pass/fail

query: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
reference_answer: An "IC" grade is assigned with instructor approval for excused unfinished work only. "IA" indicates incomplete in thesis credit, doctoral research, or multi-semester continuing courses.

query: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
reference_answer: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May (date varies)).

query: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
reference_answer: Yes. All students MUST file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar or the degree will not be awarded.

query: What must be completed before the degree conferral date?
reference_answer: All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date, and graduate students MUST have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.

query: When is the annual commencement ceremony?
reference_answer: The annual commencement ceremony is held in May.

query: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
reference_answer: Doctoral, Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who earned their degrees in the preceding September and December are invited to participate. Master’s, Ed.S., and certificate students who expect to complete their programs in May or at the end of the summer term (September) are also eligible to participate.

query: What must doctoral students do to participate in the May ceremony?
reference_answer: Doctoral students must have completed all requirements for the degree by the published deadlines for May in order to participate.
nuggets: Doctoral requirements must be completed by May deadlines

query: Do I need to register to attend commencement?
reference_answer: Yes. All graduate students who intend to participate in the May ceremony must register to attend through the Commencement Office.

query: Where can I find the intent-to-graduate deadlines?
reference_answer: On the UNH Academic Calendar.
nuggets: Deadlines listed on UNH Academic Calendar

query: Where can I read more about the graduation process?
reference_answer: More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website.
nuggets: More details on Graduate School website

query: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
reference_answer: Official academic records are maintained by the Office of the Registrar, which partners with Parchment for online transcript ordering. A student must satisfy all University accounts before the Registrar will issue a diploma.
nuggets: Accounts must be paid before diploma

query: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
reference_answer: All students MUST file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the deadline listed on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded.

query: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
reference_answer: Students must file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline listed on the UNH Academic Calendar. Degrees will not be awarded if the intent-to-graduate is not filed.
nuggets: Intent-to-graduate deadline is on the UNH Academic Calendar
Degree not awarded if not filed

query: How do I apply to grad school?
reference_answer: Persons holding a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution may apply for admission to the Graduate School. Admission is competitive and based solely on academic qualifications and potential. Application materials become part of the permanent UNH record and will not be returned. Procedures, deadlines, and program-specific requirements are available on the Graduate School website.
nuggets: Application open to holders of accredited bachelor's degree
Admission is competitive and based on academic qualifications
Application materials are permanent and not returned
Procedures and deadlines are on the Graduate School website

query: What is the application deadline?
reference_answer: Application deadlines for admission and financial aid vary by program and are updated annually on each program’s page. Deadlines may differ for UNH undergraduates, international applicants, and other student groups. Current program deadlines are available on the Graduate School website.
nuggets: Program links on Graduate School website

query: Can I take courses without applying?
reference_answer: Individuals with a bachelor's degree may register for graduate courses as non-degree students through Continuing Education. Non-degree students are not admitted to the Graduate School and may take up to 8 credits per semester; 9 or more credits require special permission, except in summer.
nuggets: Non-degree students may take graduate courses
Up to 8 credits per semester without permission
Non-degree students are not admitted to the Graduate School

query: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
reference_answer: Qualified UNH seniors with normally a 3.20 GPA may apply early and be admitted to the Graduate School before completing the bachelor's degree. After earning 90 undergraduate credits, they may register for up to 12 credits of 800-level graduate courses, which may count toward both the bachelor's and master's (12-credit limit) or a graduate certificate (8-credit limit), with departmental and Graduate School approval.
nuggets: Up to 12 credits of 800-level before bachelor's completion
Limit: 12 credits toward master's or 8 toward certificate

query: Can I defer my admission?
reference_answer: Applicants unable to enroll for the term of admission may request a one-time deferral for up to one year. Requests must be in writing. Students not active in another program must drop any current registrations. Approved deferrals prohibit registration for graduate coursework during the deferral period.
nuggets: Deferral allowed up to one year
Request must be in writing and only once
Cannot register for graduate courses during deferral

query: When is the deadline to apply for Fall 2025?
reference_answer: Application deadlines vary by graduate program, and each program publishes its own deadlines on its program page. Applicants must check their specific program page for the correct Fall 2025 application deadline.
nuggets: Check program page for exact deadline

query: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
reference_answer: Applicants apply to graduate certificate programs through the Graduate School online application and must submit required materials listed on the Graduate School website. Some programs may have additional requirements specified on their program page.
nuggets: Apply via Graduate School online application

query: Can I defer my admission offer?
reference_answer: Applicants who cannot enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request a one-time deferral for up to one year. The request must be submitted in writing, and approved deferrals do not permit enrollment in graduate coursework during the deferral period.

query: Do I need to register?
reference_answer: Students in face-to-face graduate programs must maintain continuous enrollment each semester of the academic year until their degree is formally awarded by registering for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment, unless a leave of absence is granted. Students who do not maintain continuous enrollment will have their degree status discontinued and must petition for reinstatement or readmission to return to their program. Students enrolled only in an online or certificate program are exempt from this continuous enrollment policy.
nuggets: Face-to-face grad students must maintain continuous enrollment
Noncompliance leads to degree status discontinued
Online-only and certificate students are exempt

query: How many credits can I take?
reference_answer: The maximum graduate load allowed is 16 credits, or 12 credits for a student on a full assistantship. Exceeding these limits is allowed only under unusual circumstances with the recommendation of the adviser and graduate program coordinator and the approval of the dean of the Graduate School. Students registered for more than 16 credits thirty days after the semester begins are charged full tuition plus the appropriate course charge for each additional credit, for both credit and audit courses. Tuition waivers do not cover tuition overload charges.
nuggets: Overload allowed only by petition and dean approval
Overload charges apply to credit and audit
Tuition waivers do not cover overload

query: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
reference_answer: GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment is for continuing graduate students who are not enrolled in course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900, are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy; it carries part-time status, 0 credits, and costs $200 with no additional fees. GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research is for master’s students who are in residence, need to be full time, and have already completed all course requirements and the maximum thesis or project credits; it confers full-time status at 0 credits, costs $500 plus full-time mandatory fees, and may normally be taken only once, with repeats allowed by permission.
nuggets: GRAD 800 = part-time, 0 credits, $200, for non-resident continuing enrollment
GRAD 900 = full-time, 0 credits, $500 + full-time fees, for master’s in residence after max thesis/project credits
GRAD 900 normally once; repeats by permission

query: What is full time status?
reference_answer: Graduate students registered for 9 or more credits, GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research, or Doctoral Research (999) are classified as full-time students. Students holding assistantship appointments are also considered full time and must register each semester for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900, or Doctoral Research (999).
nuggets: Assistants full time with at least 6 credits, GRAD 900, or 999

query: How do I withdraw from the program?
reference_answer: A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining and submitting a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who formally withdraw must apply for readmission if they later wish to resume their program and are required to pay an application fee plus any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the inactive period. Readmission is not guaranteed and applicants may be evaluated in competition with current applicants.
nuggets: Withdrawal requires a Graduate School withdrawal form
Readmission later requires a new application and fees
Continuing enrollment fees for inactive periods may be owed

query: Can I change my degree?
reference_answer: Students who wish to pursue a different degree program than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete an application for a change of degree. This includes UNH master’s students who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department. Forms are available on the Graduate School website, and the dean of the Graduate School will notify the student of the decision after consulting with the appropriate departments.
nuggets: Change of degree requires a formal application
Includes master’s students moving to Ph.D. in same department
Forms are on the Graduate School website

query: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
reference_answer: Students holding assistantship appointments are considered full time if they register each semester for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research, or Doctoral Research (999).
nuggets: Assistantship holders full time with at least 6 credits, GRAD 900, or 999

query: How many courses can I take during January Term (J-Term)?
reference_answer: January Term is a three-week winter session, and because of the intensive course of study, students may register for only one course during January Term.
nuggets: Students may take only one course

query: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
reference_answer: Students may withdraw from their graduate program by submitting a withdrawal form to the Graduate School. To return later, they must apply for readmission, pay a new application fee, and, if readmitted, pay any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period of inactivity. Readmission is not guaranteed.
nuggets: Withdrawal uses a Graduate School withdrawal form
Readmission needs new application and fees
Continuing enrollment fees may be due

query: Can I take a leave of absence?
reference_answer: Yes. Students who cannot pursue their graduate program due to extenuating circumstances such as medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship may request a leave of absence for up to one calendar year. They must submit a request form with documentation before the term for which the leave is requested. If approved by the dean of the Graduate School, upon recommendation of the adviser and graduate program coordinator, the program time limit is extended accordingly and the student is exempt from the continuing enrollment fee during the leave. Students who do not return from leave on time will have their degree status discontinued.
nuggets: Leave of absence allowed up to one year
Medical, military, family, or hardship reasons
Request with documentation before the term
Dean approval based on adviser and coordinator recommendation
Time limit extended and no continuing enrollment fee
Failure to return leads to degree status discontinued

query: How do I change my degree?
reference_answer: To change to a different degree program, students must complete the appropriate Change of Degree application available on the Graduate School website. The dean of the Graduate School reviews the request, consults with the relevant departments, and then notifies the student of the decision.
nuggets: Student is notified of the decision

query: What is JTerm?
reference_answer: January Term is a three-week learning opportunity held during winter break with online, on-campus, and study-away credit courses in various disciplines at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Because of the intensive format, students may register for only one course during January Term.

query: What is GRAD 800?
reference_answer: GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment is required each semester of the academic year (or each summer for M.S.T. programs) for continuing graduate students who are not enrolled in course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900, are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy. It carries part-time status, 0 credits, and costs $200 with no additional fees. New students are not eligible to enroll in GRAD 800.
nuggets: GRAD 800 for continuing students not in courses/thesis/999/GRAD 900
Required each term under continuous enrollment

query: What is GRAD 900?
reference_answer: Master’s Continuing Research (GRAD 900) is for master’s students who are in residence, need full-time status, and have already completed all course requirements and the maximum number of thesis or project credits. It is a 0-credit registration that confers full-time status, costs $500, and requires payment of full-time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, GRAD 900 may normally be taken only once, but students may repeat it with permission.
nuggets: GRAD 900 for in-residence master’s needing full-time after max thesis/project credits
Normally once; repeats allowed with permission

query: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
reference_answer: Yes. UNH offers a Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP), an affordable university-sponsored health insurance option for students. The plan is available to full-time degree students, and international students on F-1 and J-1 visas are required to purchase it.
nuggets: UNH offers the Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP)
International students on F-1/J-1 must purchase SHBP

query: Is there housing available?
reference_answer: Yes. Graduate housing is available at UNH. Babcock Hall is a unique community for students 21 and older, including international, graduate, and non-traditional students. It offers single-occupancy rooms, each with a personal mini fridge. For full details, students should contact UNH Housing.
nuggets: Mix of international, graduate, and non-traditional students
Single occupancy rooms with mini fridge

query: Where can I find information about graduate housing?
reference_answer: Graduate housing information can be found through UNH Housing. Babcock Hall houses students aged 21 and older, including graduate and international students, with details available on the UNH Housing website under Graduate Housing.
nuggets: Graduate housing details on UNH Housing site

query: What financial aid is available?
reference_answer: Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, including tuition scholarships, assistantships, dissertation fellowships, and summer fellowships. To be eligible for any assistance, a student must first be admitted to the Graduate School, and in many cases the admission application serves as the funding application.
nuggets: Several forms of financial assistance are available through the Graduate School and departments
Includes scholarships, assistantships, dissertation fellowships, summer fellowships
Students must be admitted to the Graduate School to be eligible

query: Where can I find information about assistantships?
reference_answer: Information about assistantships and other graduate appointments is described under Graduate Appointments. Graduate appointments are made to students admitted to the Graduate School on the recommendation of their department or program, and students are advised to contact their departmental graduate coordinator with questions about award amounts and opportunities.
nuggets: Assistantships are described under Graduate Appointments
Appointments require admission plus departmental recommendation
Students should contact their departmental graduate coordinator for details

query: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
reference_answer: Students holding full-time assistantships are charged 50% of the full-time mandatory fees rate. Assistants, fellows, and lecturers receive a waiver for the technology fee and course fees, but mandatory fees themselves are not covered by waivers, although scholarships may be awarded to help cover them.
nuggets: Full-time assistants pay 50% of mandatory fees
Technology and course fees are waived
Mandatory fees are not waived but scholarships may cover them

query: How much are graduate assistants paid?
reference_answer: For 2025–2026, standard stipend levels are: Level 1 – $22,890 for all master’s students and doctoral students with a bachelor’s degree and less than two years of GA or RA experience at UNH; Level 2 – $24,010 for doctoral students with a master’s degree or with two years of GA or RA experience; Level 3 – $25,310 for doctoral students at candidacy.

query: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
reference_answer: Graduate students typically apply for assistantships and scholarships through their academic department or graduate program. In many cases, the application for admission with supporting documents also serves as the application for available scholarship and assistantship programs, though some departments require additional departmental forms.
nuggets: Funding applications are usually handled through the student’s department or program
Admission materials often serve as the application for scholarships and assistantships
Some departments have their own additional application forms

query: What is the registration requirement for graduate assistants?
reference_answer: During each semester of their appointment, assistants, fellows, and graduate part-time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course or thesis credits, Master’s Continuing Research (GRAD 900), or Doctoral Research (999).
nuggets: Assistants, fellows, and graduate part-time lecturers must register each semester
Minimum of 6 course/thesis credits or GRAD 900 or 999

query: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Traditional full-time students can normally complete the M.S. in Biotech:IBMS in 18 months. UNH bachelor’s students admitted to the Accelerated Master’s program as full-time students can complete the degree in as little as 12 months, depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. As part of the program, students choosing project or internship options complete applied research or internships, while students choosing the co-op route spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement.
nuggets: Traditional full-time completion in about 18 months
Accelerated Master’s completion in as little as 12 months for UNH bachelor’s students
Co-op option includes a 6-month full-time industrial placement

query: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
reference_answer: Both the traditional and accelerated formats of the M.S. in Biotech:IBMS require students to complete 30 credits. These include 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total core credits), 8–14 credits of elective coursework, and 3–9 credits of capstone experience.
nuggets: Includes 4 Core Curriculum courses plus a Graduate Biotech Seminar (13 credits)

query: How many credits are required in the Core Curriculum for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The Core Curriculum, consisting of four core courses plus a Graduate Biotech Seminar course, requires 13 credits in total.
nuggets: 13 credits of core curriculum including seminar

query: How many elective credits are required in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Students complete between 8 and 14 credits of elective coursework in the program.

query: What is the credit range for the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The Capstone Experience requires between 3 and 9 credits, depending on the capstone option and the number of hours spent in the experience.

query: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
reference_answer: Students become eligible to begin their capstone experience after completing 9 credits in the M.S. Biotechnology program, at which point they are required to enroll in at least one capstone credit (BIOT 891, BIOT 892, BIOT 895, or BIOT 889).
nuggets: Capstone can begin only after completion of 9 credits
At least one credit of capstone enrollment is then required

query: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses that build industry-relevant transferrable skills such as clear communication, teamwork, cooperation, conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving alongside wet-lab skills. It covers major industry areas in cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry and includes the course Biotechnology Products and Regulation, which examines biotechnology from research and development through legal and regulatory stages. Students also take at least one graduate biotech seminar focusing on topics such as instrumentation in the biotech industry and cutting-edge biotech issues.
nuggets: Core built around research project team-based lab courses
Develops industry-relevant transferrable skills plus wet-lab skills
Includes Biotech Products and Regulation on R&D through regulatory stages
Requires at least one graduate biotech seminar on instrumentation or cutting-edge topics

query: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?
reference_answer: Students develop a curriculum plan that includes elective courses in consultation with their Faculty Advisor, and this plan is customized to their career goals.
nuggets: Curriculum and electives are planned with a Faculty Advisor
Plan is customized to the student’s career goals

query: How many total program credits are composed of core, elective, and capstone work in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The program combines 13 credits of core curriculum and seminar, 8–14 credits of electives, and 3–9 credits of capstone work for a total of 30 credits.
nuggets: Combination of core, elective, and capstone credits

query: What is the main goal of the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The capstone is designed as a substantial applied experience—either research in a UNH Manchester laboratory, an internship or applied research in an industry setting, or a full-time co-op placement—planned with a faculty advisor or internship/co-op coordinator to align with the student’s career development plans.

Capstone is designed and approved to align with the student’s career development plans

query: What does each credit in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program represent in academic work?
reference_answer: Under UNH’s credit hour policy for graduate coursework, each credit hour represents, at a minimum, the equivalent of about three hours of student academic work per week over a standard 15-week term, including both direct instruction and independent study.
nuggets: Each credit hour corresponds to about three hours of academic work per week
Credit hour definition includes both class time and independent work

query: Who supervises the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: The capstone experience is designed and approved by the student’s Faculty Advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator. Research-based capstones are typically carried out in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s laboratory (often the Faculty Advisor), while internships and co-ops take place in industry settings with oversight coordinated through the program.
nuggets: Capstone is designed and approved by the Faculty Advisor or internship/co-op coordinator
Research capstones are typically in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s lab

query: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Academically, the program focuses on research project team-based lab courses and core lab and lecture work in major industry areas such as cell biology, molecular biology, and protein biochemistry. It also emphasizes understanding biotechnology products and regulation from early research and development through legal and regulatory stages, and exposes students to current instrumentation and cutting-edge topics in the biotech industry through graduate seminars.
nuggets: Emphasis on research project team-based lab courses
Core coverage of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry
Includes a Biotechnology Products and Regulation course on R&D through regulatory stages
Seminars on instrumentation and cutting-edge biotech topics

query: Does the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program integrate academic and professional preparation?
reference_answer: Yes. The program integrates academic coursework in core lab and lecture courses and seminars with professional preparation through an applied capstone experience in a research lab, internship, or co-op that is explicitly designed to fit the student’s career development plans.

Capstone placements in research labs, internships, or co-ops are aligned with career development

query: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

query: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree. Accelerated master's programs are designed to provide students with an efficient and cost-effective pathway to earn both a bachelor's and master's degree or graduate certificate, enhancing career opportunities and long-term earning potential.

query: What are the admission requirements for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?

query: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Demonstrate mastery of core knowledge in fundamental biochemical, cellular, and molecular biological principles, concepts, and theories.
nuggets: fundamental biochemical, cellular, and molecular biological principles

query: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Demonstrate high-level practical laboratory skill in the areas of mammalian cell culture, molecular biology and microbiology, and protein techniques.

query: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

query: How will students communicate technical information in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Demonstrate the ability to communicate high-level technical information related to biotechnology in scientific writing and oral presentations to a variety of audiences.

query: How do students engage with research literature in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Understand, analyze, evaluate, and summarize primary research literature involving biotechnology related topics.

query: How is the scientific method applied in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Understand and apply the process of the scientific method, including being able to formulate hypotheses, design and conduct experiments with adequate controls to test hypotheses, interpret and evaluate data, and draw conclusions.

query: What quantitative and data skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Demonstrate expertise in quantitative skills including basic math and statistics, use of spreadsheet or statistical software, and graphical presentation of quantitative data.

query: What transferable professional skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Deploy important biotechnology industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

query: What leadership outcome is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Demonstrate the ability to function as a member and leader of a team.

query: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Successfully undertake a substantial Capstone experience (in industry or in an academic laboratory) in which the student demonstrates sufficient knowledge of the professional, experimental, ethical, communication, and laboratory standards relevant to the selected placement.

query: What specialty development is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
reference_answer: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

query: phd time limit?
reference_answer: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field. A Ph.D. student must be advanced to candidacy within five years after matriculation or within four years if the student entered with a master's in the same field. Years on leave do not count toward the time limit.

query: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
